title: 103_hr4897
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act of 1994" allows for the seizure of lottery winnings, settlements, payouts, and sale of forfeited property to pay child support arrearages. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for imposing a lien on lottery winnings or gambling payouts to pay child support arrearages. The distributor must suspend payment until the state child support agency confirms the debt. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act requires the suspension of lottery winnings or gambling payouts until the state child support agency confirms any child support arrearages. Payments under insurance policies or settlements must also be suspended until the agency confirms arrearages, with the amount withheld being the lesser of the payment or arrearage. The payor must suspend payments from lottery winnings, gambling payouts, insurance policies, or settlements until the state child support agency confirms any child support arrearages. The withheld amount should be the lesser of the payment or arrearage. If the State seizes property forfeited by an individual due to a criminal conviction, they must hold the property until the state agency confirms any child support arrearages. If there are arrearages, the property should be sold to satisfy the claims. After satisfying all other claimants and deducting costs, the remaining proceeds or arrearage amount is paid to the State agency for distribution. Payment in respect to a decedent should be suspended until the State agency confirms eligibility. The state agency determines if the person owes child support arrears and withholds the payment to cover the arrears, paying the withheld amount to the state agency for distribution. SEC. 3. RESTRICTIONS RELATING TO PROFESSIONAL, OCCUPATIONAL, BUSINESS, AND DRIVER'S LICENSES. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for State licensing departments to withhold licenses from noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants and individuals delinquent in child support payments. Child support enforcement allows for the release of license holds or expedited review for individuals with outstanding child support warrants. State motor vehicle departments are prohibited from issuing or renewing licenses for noncustodial parents with warrants related to child support proceedings. State motor vehicle departments must suspend the driver's license or vehicle registration of individuals with child support warrants, and may issue temporary licenses pending compliance with the order or warrant removal. SEC. 4. ATTACHMENT OF BANK ACCOUNTS. Section 466(a) (42 U.S.C. 666(a)) is amended to allow seizure of funds in a bank account to pay child support arrears through an administrative process, with notice and opportunity to be heard for the account holder. The amendment allows seizure of funds from a bank account to pay child support arrears if the account holder fails to challenge the seizure successfully. The institution may have to pay the arrearage amount or the amount in the account to the entity collecting the arrears. SEC. 5. Reporting of child support obligations to credit bureaus is amended to require courts or agencies to report individual names and amounts of child support obligations to consumer reporting agencies. SEC. 6. Liability of grandparents for financial support of their grandchildren. SEC. 6. Liability of grandparents for financial support of their grandchildren. Amends the Social Security Act to make each parent liable for the financial support of their child if the individual is unable to provide such support.
